moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 e6
1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 e6 7. O-O Be7 8. f4 O-O 9. Kh1
comment: With this move White prepares to move Qd1 without worries that Nd4 might be pinned on the a7-g1 diagonal.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 e6 7. O-O Be7 8. f4 O-O 9. Kh1 Qc7 10. a4 Nc6 11. Be3 Re8 12. Bf3
comment: I usually don't care for the bishop here because Black can often play ...e6-e5 to block Pe4 and Bf3.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 e6 7. O-O Be7 8. f4 O-O 9. Kh1 Qc7 10. a4 Nc6 11. Be3 Re8 12. Bf3 Rb8
comment: aiming for ...b7-b5, which Be2-f3 allows. He also removes the rook from the diagonal alignment with Bf3.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 e6 7. O-O Be7 8. f4 O-O 9. Kh1 Qc7 10. a4 Nc6 11. Be3 Re8 12. Bf3 Rb8 13. Qd2
comment: This isn't the best location for the queen, though it could go to f2. He seems to be begging Black to invade on the c-file!

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 e6 7. O-O Be7 8. f4 O-O 9. Kh1 Qc7 10. a4 Nc6 11. Be3 Re8 12. Bf3 Rb8 13. Qd2 Bd7 14. Nb3 b6
comment: Black's hedgehog position is sturdy. Anand has learned well from Kasparov (and others before him) .

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 e6 7. O-O Be7 8. f4 O-O 9. Kh1 Qc7 10. a4 Nc6 11. Be3 Re8 12. Bf3 Rb8 13. Qd2 Bd7 14. Nb3 b6 15. Rae1 Bc8 16. e5
comment: Ivanchuk bites the bullet and tries to force things to his advantage. But, Black's position is fairly resilient. If the f-file opens Pf7 could be a problem.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 e6 7. O-O Be7 8. f4 O-O 9. Kh1 Qc7 10. a4 Nc6 11. Be3 Re8 12. Bf3 Rb8 13. Qd2 Bd7 14. Nb3 b6 15. Rae1 Bc8 16. e5 dxe5 17. Bxc6
comment: else the Bf3 would be of no use and Rf1 would remain blocked.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 e6 7. O-O Be7 8. f4 O-O 9. Kh1 Qc7 10. a4 Nc6 11. Be3 Re8 12. Bf3 Rb8 13. Qd2 Bd7 14. Nb3 b6 15. Rae1 Bc8 16. e5 dxe5 17. Bxc6 Qxc6 18. fxe5 Nd5
comment: Black seeks simplifying exchanges now that he has the two bishops advantage.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 e6 7. O-O Be7 8. f4 O-O 9. Kh1 Qc7 10. a4 Nc6 11. Be3 Re8 12. Bf3 Rb8 13. Qd2 Bd7 14. Nb3 b6 15. Rae1 Bc8 16. e5 dxe5 17. Bxc6 Qxc6 18. fxe5 Nd5 19. Qf2 Rf8 20. Nxd5 Qxd5 21. Bxb6 Bb7
comment: Bb6 is still challenged because Black intends Qxg2+ to regain the pawn.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 e6 7. O-O Be7 8. f4 O-O 9. Kh1 Qc7 10. a4 Nc6 11. Be3 Re8 12. Bf3 Rb8 13. Qd2 Bd7 14. Nb3 b6 15. Rae1 Bc8 16. e5 dxe5 17. Bxc6 Qxc6 18. fxe5 Nd5 19. Qf2 Rf8 20. Nxd5 Qxd5 21. Bxb6 Bb7 22. Bc5 Bh4
comment: The tactics are challenging. Black threatens mate at g2. White threatens Rf8. Black threatens Qf2. All-in-all I think Black is fine because all his pieces are active, while White's Re1 and Nb3 can't do much.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 e6 7. O-O Be7 8. f4 O-O 9. Kh1 Qc7 10. a4 Nc6 11. Be3 Re8 12. Bf3 Rb8 13. Qd2 Bd7 14. Nb3 b6 15. Rae1 Bc8 16. e5 dxe5 17. Bxc6 Qxc6 18. fxe5 Nd5 19. Qf2 Rf8 20. Nxd5 Qxd5 21. Bxb6 Bb7 22. Bc5 Bh4 23. Qe2 Rfc8 24. Rd1 Qe4 25. Qxe4 Bxe4
comment: Now Black threatens to remove Pc2 which supports Nb3 and that supports Bc5. It's close to a dynamic equality.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 e6 7. O-O Be7 8. f4 O-O 9. Kh1 Qc7 10. a4 Nc6 11. Be3 Re8 12. Bf3 Rb8 13. Qd2 Bd7 14. Nb3 b6 15. Rae1 Bc8 16. e5 dxe5 17. Bxc6 Qxc6 18. fxe5 Nd5 19. Qf2 Rf8 20. Nxd5 Qxd5 21. Bxb6 Bb7 22. Bc5 Bh4 23. Qe2 Rfc8 24. Rd1 Qe4 25. Qxe4 Bxe4 26. Bd6 Bxc2 27. Bxb8 Bxd1 28. Rxd1 Rxb8 29. Na5
comment: I have no idea why he'd just toss away Pb2.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 e6 7. O-O Be7 8. f4 O-O 9. Kh1 Qc7 10. a4 Nc6 11. Be3 Re8 12. Bf3 Rb8 13. Qd2 Bd7 14. Nb3 b6 15. Rae1 Bc8 16. e5 dxe5 17. Bxc6 Qxc6 18. fxe5 Nd5 19. Qf2 Rf8 20. Nxd5 Qxd5 21. Bxb6 Bb7 22. Bc5 Bh4 23. Qe2 Rfc8 24. Rd1 Qe4 25. Qxe4 Bxe4 26. Bd6 Bxc2 27. Bxb8 Bxd1 28. Rxd1 Rxb8 29. Na5 Rxb2 30. g3 Be7 31. Nc6 Bf8 32. Rd8 g5 33. h4 gxh4 34. gxh4 Rc2 35. Nb8 Kg7 36. Rd4
comment: and just like that Black has ended the threats to achieve a won ending: bishop v. knight and extra pawn.
